subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Bear and Beer
msgSnippet: ... I know, it s strange how different dialects can be. My girlfriend shares your surprise, and I am equally surprised that these words are pronounced
messageBody:
C. Paige Gabhart wrote:
>
>
> Paul:
>
> As is probably typical with dialects, it never crossed my mind that
> anyone would pronounce "bear" and "beer" the same since they seem so
> clearly different to me. You stated you can't hear the difference
> between the two words. I am not sure what that means. Is that just
> another way of saying you pronounce them the same?
>
> For example, can you hear the difference between "hair" and "here"? For
> me these words rhyme with the bear - beer example. Do you pronounces
> hair and here the same? And if you hear the vowel difference between
> hair and here, then you must be able to hear the vowel difference
> between bear and beer even if you don't make the distinction yourself.
>
> One last question. I don't remember you saying how you pronounced.bear
> and beer other than the same. Do you pronounce "bear" like "beer" or is
> it the other way round?
>

I know, it's strange how different dialects can be. My girlfriend shares
your surprise, and I am equally surprised that these words are
pronounced differently. Yes, I do pronounce "hair" and "here" the same.
I assume that my Boston accent causes this merger, but it could also be
an idosyncrisy with my speech.

I pronounce both with the /i/ sound. If I were to write "bear" and
"bear" in QS, I would write both words "Bob Eat Roar."

This merger can be handled easily. Now that I am aware of the
difference, I am starting to hear that difference when others speak.
Using QS would make most users somewhat more aware of these differences.
If I really wanted to avoid confusion when writing QS, I would look up
any word that I rhyme with "here" in a dictionary. On the other hand, if
I wrote both "beer" and "bear" with "Bob Eat Roar," I would probably be
understood perfectly.

Paul
